Abstract
Organ ischemia with inadequate oxygen supply followed by reperfusion (which initiates a
complex of inflammatory responses and oxidative stress) occurs in different clinical conditions
and surgical procedures including stroke, myocardial infarction, limb ischemia, renal failure,
organ transplantation, free-tissue-transfer, cardiopulmonary bypass, and vascular surgery. Even
though pharmacological treatment protect against experimental ischemia reperfusion (I/R) injury,
there has not been enough success for their applications in patient benefits. The main hurdles in
treatment of I/R injury are the lack of diagnosis tools for understanding the complicated chains
of I/R-induced signaling events, especially in acute phase after ischemia, determining the
affected regions of the tissue over time, and then, targeting and safe delivery of antioxidants,
drugs, peptides, genes and cells to the areas required treatment. Beside the innate antioxidant and
free radical scavenging properties of some nanoparticles, they show higher flexibilities in drug
delivery and imaging purposes. This review highlights three main approaches on I/R injury
targeting by nanoparticles; 1) antioxidant nanoparticles on reducing tissue oxidative stress, 2)
targeted delivery of therapeutic agents to the ischemic regions or cells, and 3) imaging I/R injury
at molecular, cellular or tissue level and monitoring its evolution using contrasts induced by
nanoparticles. These approaches can also be combined to realize so called theranostics for
providing simultaneous diagnosis of ischemic regions and treatments by targeted delivery.
Keywords : Nanoparticles, Ischemia-reperfusion injury, Infarction, Nanomedicine, Drug
delivery, Diagnosis, Graphene materials

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Ischemia reperfusion (I/R) is characterized by initial arterial occlusion, restriction of the blood supply to an organ, with subsequent perfusion. Organ ischemia is the underlying pathology for many clinical conditions including stroke, myocardial infarction, acute kidney injury, limb ischemia, solid organ transplantation, as well as cardiopulmonary and main arterial surgeries.1 Considering only myocardial infarction as a major cause of death and disability on the globe and lack of effective cardioprotective therapy in clinical practice necessitates the development of new therapies. 2

sections.heading: 1.1. Molecular mechanisms of ischemia reperfusion injury
sections.text: Ischemia or hypoxia induces oxidative stress, release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, subsequent cellular damages, and death. The reduction of tissue glucose and oxygen supplies which, in turn, results in low ATP level in cells. Oxidative stress and associated oxidative damage are leading causes of cellular injury in ischemic condition. Mediators of oxidative stress are reactive oxygen species (ROS) including superoxide radical anion, hydroxyl radical, singlet oxygen, and hydrogen peroxide that damage cellular targets such as DNA, proteins, and lipids. 3 After ischemia, reperfusion may cause a sequential chain of the pathophysiological cascades including massive intracellular Ca 2+ release, mitochondrial electron transport chain impairment, recruitment of neutrophils, acute inflammatory responses and generation of free radicals which, in turn, enhance apoptotic or necrotic cell death. 4

sections.heading: 1.2. Nanomaterials: an advanced approach in treatment of ischemia reperfusion
sections.text:
The some strategies to reduce I/R-induced tissue damage relays on endogenous protection,
pharmacological treatments and the use of nano-scale devices. 5, 6 Varity of experimental
ischemic and pharmacological conditioning strategies have been tested in clinical settings over
past 30 years and the results confirmed the challenges of translating the experimental findings to
patients benefit. Rapidly developing field of nanotechnology offers promising future to
overcome the issues related to pharmacological treatment of ischemic tissue.7 Unique
physicochemical properties of materials at the nanolevel such as large surface-to-volume ratio,
surface chemistry, and possibility of targeted delivery to desired tissues make them good
candidates for biomedical applications. 8-10 The importance of the drug delivery in stroke and
ischemic disease emerge when managing the time is the most important parameter after

ischemia. 11 Decreased blood flow to the affected tissue or its rapid metabolization by liver
decreases availability of the drug to the affected organ.12 Considering other barriers, e.g. blood
brain barrier (BBB) on stroke, the lack of an appropriate delivery system seems to be more
critical parameter in defining the outcome of damage. 13 Nanomaterials offer potentials for break
down of clots, efficient targeted delivery of stem cells and anti- ROS molcules to ischemic areas
and their distribution, as well as decreasing its hepatic metabolization rate(figure1).14, 15
figure1. Various nanoplatforms for treatment of ischemic regions in heart tissue. Adapted
from. 2
Moreover, some nanoparticles shows antioxidant properties or they have been used as
diagnostic tools to detect the ischemic areas. 16, 17 In this paper potential uses of nanomaterials
will be discussed for diagnosis and the treatment of I/R injury of different organs. We
categorized their application in three subject 1) nanoparticles which show antioxidant properties,
2) nanoparticles for targeted delivery of drugs to the ischemic regions, 3) nanoparticles on
diagnosis of I/R injury.

sections.heading: 2. Antioxidant nanomaterials
sections.text:
The endogenous antioxidant defence system of our body can neutralize the toxic effect of
ROS by both enzymatic (such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione

peroxidase, GSH-Px and glutathione-S-transferase (GST)) and non-enzymatic (such as
glutathione) reactions.18 There are also external sources of antioxidants such as herbaceous
polyphenols which play an important role against oxidative stress by targeting different cellular
signaling pathway and subsequently up-regulation of endogenous antioxidant defenses. 19-21
Regarding the redox property of some nanoparticles, they can be exploited as possible
biologically active antioxidants. Owing to large surface area-to- volume ratio of nanomaterials,
higher ratios of active electrons can be found on the outer surface, resulting in increasing their
catalytic activity (here, antioxidant activity). 22 For instance, metal oxide nanomaterials can
potentially be involved in effective ROS scavenging and/or deoxygenating reactions.23, 24 In
recent years, an increasing number of studies have emphasize d that nanomaterials can mimic the
properties of antioxidant enzymes to inhibit apoptosis and improve the cell survival after I/R
injury. 25, 26 In the light of these findings, a brief review on potential antioxidant activity of some
nanomaterials is presented in the following.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Cerium oxide (CeO2, ceria) nanoparticles
sections.text:
CeO2 is a metal oxide with potential redox activity, due to the quick mutations between
cerium (IV), Ce 4+ , and cerium (III), Ce 3+ , oxidation states. In its bulk state, reduction of the Ce 4+
to Ce 3+ leaves oxygen vacancies in the lattice, while the stabilized oxygen vacancies in NPs
makes it more effective at generating Ce 3+ . 27 As shown in figure 2, CeO2 NPs with oxygen
buffering properties in water give rise to excellent catalytic properties which mimics free-radical
scavenging properties of the antioxidant enzymes and the activity of both superoxide oxidase and
catalase in scavenging the intracellular ROS and improve cell survival under oxidative stress. 28

Meantime, use of ultra-small nanoparticles with sizes < 4 nm significantly increases the catalytic
activity of CeO. 29 These NPs are also potent antioxidants with a substantial oxygen storage and
release capacity via interchangeable surface. The redox cycle of the NPs results in their
accumulation on the mitochondrial outer membrane and plasma membrane, resulting in
prevention of amyloid beta-induced mitochondrial fragmentation in neural tissues (due to
decreasing both reactive nitrogen species (RNS) and ROS). 30, 31

Figure 2 a) Autocatalytic behavior of CeO NP in water, resulting in a general free-radical
scavenging property b, c) high neuronal survival in treated cultures after 15 - 30 day and in th
precence of 100Mm H2O2 respectively. 32
It is also reported that CeO2 NPs accelerate the decay of peroxynitrite (ONOO−) that can
generate hydroxyl and nitrogen dioxide radicals. Both of these potent radicals with an unpaired
electron can modulate oxidization of Ce 3+ to Ce 4+ at the particle surface with the continual
release of hydroxyl ion or nitrite. 33
In the in vitro model of cardiac ischemia (H2O2 treated
cardiac progenitor cells in dish), CeO NPs provided a strong and stable protection for 7 days
without affecting their growth and function. 34 Recently, another report by Bailey et al.
investigated the antioxidant mechanism of CeO NPs on traumatic brain injury outcome. They
found that CeO NPs improved neural survival and cognitive function via preservation of
endogenous antioxidant systems and decreasing of macromolecular free radical damage. 35 On the
other hand, down-regulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines by europium-doped Ceria NPs was
found to be associated with amelioration of intestinal IR injury. 36
Likewise, Ce NPs possess phosphatase mimetic activity. The emerging evidence now show
that the chemistry and active sites of CeNPs involved in catalase mimetic activity are differ from
those involved in mimicking phosphatase. 37

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Platinum nanoparticles (PtNs)
sections.text:
Platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) are extensively used in cosmetics because of their antioxidant
effects. PtNs with high ratio of their surface free electrons are able to catalyze and quench
superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide by converting O2 ●- to H2O2, and H2O2 to H2O, and O2. 38
These properties of Pt NPs mimic the antioxidant enzymatic activity including peroxidase, SOD

and CAT (figure 3a). 39 For instance, PtNs strongly reduced the levels of intracellular O2 ●- and
protected HeLa cells from ROS-related death. 40 Likewise, the antioxidant mechanisms of Pt NPs
can be attributed to their mitochondrial complex I NADH ubiquinone oxidoreductase mimetic
activity, catechol oxidase-like activity and the ability to inhibit lipid peroxidation. 41 Similar to
CeO NPs, Pt NPs exhibit a surface chemistry and size dependent antioxidant activity. For
example, Katsumi et al. reported that administrated smaller size (36 nm) of Pt NPs before liver
I/R in mice model protected hepatic tissue against oxidative damage more than larger size
(106 nm). 42
Owing to in vitro antioxidant properties of Pt NPs, they have been applied for treatments of
several models of organ ischemia reperfusion injuries. The Pt NPs has also been applied in
treatment of ischemic stroke on mice and strongly decreased ROS production in brain tissue,
decreased brain damage and ameliorated neurological functions (Figure 3b). 43, 44

mice 48 hours after transient cerebral ischemia, which shows restricted infraction size in the Pt
NP treated mice. Adapted from ref. 45

Nevertheless, a lot more careful studies should be carried out to understand the detailed
mechanisms of the interactions between Pt NPs and chemical components of consumer products
for their safe applications in clinical trials. For instance, a recent study shows that the ascorbate
oxidase-mimetic activity of Pt NPs inhibits antioxidant activity of sodium L-ascorbate for
scavenging of free radicals. 46

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Gold nanoparticles (GNPs)
sections.text:
Among various metal nanoparticles, GNPs have further been studied and used in versatile
biological applications, because of being inert and resistance to surface oxidation. 47 The GNPs
paradoxically and size-dependently act as both oxidants and antioxidants in biological systems. 48
The antioxidant property of GNPs has been confirmed in controlling the hyperglycemic
conditions on diabetic mice by restoring antioxidant enzymes function (GSH, SOD, CAT and
GPx), scavenging ROS and decreasing lipid peroxidation. 49 It has been shown that GNPs with
diameter of ~25 nm can ameliorate the production of oxidants, and decreases oxidative damages,
while enhance the antioxidant defensive systems in adult rats. On cerebral ischemia reperfusion
model, 20 nm GNPs administration resulted in remarkable reduction of infarction volume,
increasing the expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokines and anti-apoptotic proteins, as well
as decreasing the expression of pro-apoptotic proteins. All of these confirmed in vivo antioxidant
properties on GNPs for cerebral ischemia models. 50 Furthermore, unique surface chemistry of
GNPs provides possibility of their surface decoration with other ROS scavengers or anti-
inflammatory agents to enhance their antioxidant activity in coping with I/R injury. 51

Selenium (Se) which plays a critical role in redox reactions is known as an essential element
in the health of mammalians. Se improves the activity of the selenoenzymes and delays onset and
progression of neurodegenerative diseases.52 In recent years Se NPs have attracted tremendous
interest from the scientific community as novel candidates in the management of oxidative stress
owing to unique their properties including low toxicity, lots of surface active centers, excellent
surface activity, high catalytic efficiency and strong adsorbing ability. 53
Direct antioxidant activity of Se NPs was already studied at three different size ranges; 5-15
nm, 20-60 nm and 80-200 nm. The results showed that the Se NPs can effectively scavenge
different free radicals, such as superoxide anion, singlet oxygen and NO. The scavenging effect
was size dependent, namely, the smaller the stronger. 54 The antioxidant activity of Se NPs was
also studied on the in vitro models of ischemia reperfusion injury. The protective effect of Se
NPs against oxidative stress is associated with alteration of the innate antioxidant status
(glutathione, and antioxidant enzymes) and mitochondrial function. 55, 56 Even tough, the effect of Se
NPs on in vivo models of I/R injury has remained to be clarified by future studies.

sections.heading: 2.2. Carbon-based nanomaterials
sections.text:
The carbon-based nanomaterials (often including graphene-based materials) comprise an
extensive spectra of structures from zero-dimensional structures (fullerenes, diamond clusters),
to one-dimensional (nanotubes), two-dimensional (graphene), and three-dimensional structures
(nanocrystalline diamond, fullerite, and graphite) (figure 4a). Carbon-based nanomaterials can
generate ROS because of the presence of the heteroatoms in chemically modified nanocarbons.57
On the other hand, carbon-based nanomaterials may also show ROS scavenging effects. 58 A
hypothetic mechanism for antioxidant chemistry of graphene-based materials has been proposed

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Fullerenes
sections.text:
The fullerene (one of the allotropes of carbon which usually forms as C60 and C70) is a
soccer ball-shaped carbon cage with unique surface chemistry that provides the possibility of its
simple and extensive surface decoration for biomedical applications. 60, 61 Chemical structure of
fullerene with abundance of conjugated double bonds and low lying lowest unoccupied
molecular orbital (LUMO) makes it highly receptive to the radical species. Due to such catalytic
property, fullerene can react with many superoxides without being consumed.62 Antioxidant
functionality of fullerene depends on its ability for absorbing electrons and their dispersing
through the 3D -conjugated structure distributed over its surface. 63 In fact, fullerenes behave as
‘‘free radical sponges’’ and their micro molar concentrations can show antioxidant activity in
elimination of both superoxide anion and H2O2. It is worth mentioning that π-conjugation of the
fullerenols facilitate its covalent interaction with the –OH groups of different molecules such as
cellulose nanocrystals(CNC) which, in turn, result in enhanced colloidal stability, reduced
tendency to form clusters and higher accessibility to 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) free
radicals ( figure 4b). 64
In spite of superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity which may lead to excessive production of
H2O2, fullerene coordinated effect on scavenging superoxide anion and H2O2 does not lead to
increased H2O2 production. 65 Emerging evidences show that fullerene C60 contribute to cell
survival via alteration of the cellular redox state and enzyme activities. 66 Derivatizing fullerenes
with a polar group makes them water soluble, e.g. polyhydroxylated fullerenes (fullerenol) and

carboxyfullerenes. These fullerenes can pass the cell membrane and localize to the mitochondria
which is the source of the oxygen free radicals.67 It has also been proved that carboxyfullerenes
prevented from mitochondrial membrane disruption and leakage, which is the triggering step in
apoptosis. 68 Different derivatives of fullerenes have been applied to ischemic tissue to find out
their potential effects on reducing oxidative damage and preserving tissue function after
ischemia(Table 1). Fullerenes C60 have most frequently been described as antioxidants,
although in biological systems they can paradoxically act as both oxidants and antioxidants.
Thompson et al. reported that intratracheal or intravenous administration of C60 fullerene
increases myocardial infarction size and coronary artery contraction after cardiac I/R injury in
rats. 69 For these controversial findings, size, structure and surface chemistry of fullerenes may
determine their antioxidant activity and biological behavior if they contribute to cell survival
against oxidative stress or enhance cancerous cell death. For instance, Hsu et al. demonstrated
that the different surface functional groups could exert distinct regulations of the oxygen
metabolism in target cells to induce or reduce the generation of ROS(figure 4 c). 70

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Graphene
sections.text:

offers great potentials for upcoming nanomedicine, including detection of single nucleotide polymorphisms of DNA, early diagnosis of cancer, and cancer therapy. 75-77 The basic chemical activity of GO, reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and few-layer graphene (FLG) against different ROS were evaluated in a single study by Qui et al. 78 All graphene-based materials showed strong activity against hydroxyl (OH), modest activity against hydrogen peroxide and lipid peroxyl radicals and stable radicals including 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) and 2,2′- azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulphonic acid) (ABTS). 79 OH radical scavenging capacity of graphen-based nanomaterials was in the following order; FLG>rGO>GO. 78 Pristine sp 2 -carbon domains are considered as the main radical scavenging site and acts through adduct formation or electron transfer. 80 Graphene-based materials also prevent from photochemical ROS production by absorbing UV (figure 5a). Although in some studies GO and rGO was found as the source of ROS generation, it was also found that the methods applied for GO reduction can affect and control the ROS level generated by rGO. 81 Therefore, antioxidant activity of graphene-based materials strongly depends on their electron density, chemical composition, sp 2 -hybridized carbon content and chemical properties (originated from the method used in the synthesis). For instance, the reduction of GO by herbal antioxidants enhances its antioxidant activity against scavenging of 1,1-Diphenyl-2- picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) free radicals. 82 In an another report by Ruiz et al. synthesized graphene quantum dots (GQD) with strong hydrogen donor behavior and large content of sp 2 -hybridized carbon domains exert higher ability than other types to scavenge free radical and ROS (Figure 5b,c,d). 83 Graphene can promisingly be applied in any kind of tissue injuries using stem cell-based tissue engineering or any other suitable techniques. 74, 84 ROS generated in the ischemic myocardium following reperfusion decrease survival of Mesenchymal stem cells ( MSCs) implanted to treat myocardial infarction (MI). Kim et al. studied the antioxidant mechanism of GO flakes for protection the implanted MSCs from ROSmediated death after MI. They found that GO flakes provided a platform for MSC adhesion and hampered a series of adverse cell-signaling cascades which, in turn, led to the anoikis of MSCs in response to ROS. 85 Graphene foam, as a 3D class of graphene architectures, has attracted much attention as a neural interface material because of its excellent topographical properties can provoke anti-inflammatory responses via the restriction of microglia morphological transformation on the surface. 86, 87 Moreover, there is a close association between antioxidant and free radical scavenging effects of graphene foam and its sp 2 -carbon network. sections.heading: 2.2.3. Nanotubes
sections.text: Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are cylindrical molecules composed of one or more graphene layers (single-wall or multiwall). The extensive application of the CNTs is related to their chemical stability, electrical conductivity and mechanical strength. Regardless of their potential for industrial applications they can present cytotoxic.89 However, there are studies which suggested a ROS scavenging effect related to the conjugated C==C chains on the CNT structure which is similar to the carotenoids. 90 It has been shown that multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) prevented from oxidation of the polystyrene, polyethylene and polypropylene. However, the effect was not as strong as the phenolic antioxidants. 91 Purified MWCNTs in aqueous solution showed strong capacity on scavenging the superoxide and hydroxyl radicals and this effect was independent on the source of the ROS. Despite the acute oxidative effect of PEGylated singlewall CNTs (SWCNT-PEG) on rat hippocampus, its long-term effect, one week after injection, appeared by increased expression of the antioxidant enzymes genes, improved antioxidant defense and reduced ROS production. 92 Such delayed antioxidant response to SWCNT-PEG proposed an adaptive, conditioning, response in tissue. This property of SWCNT-PEG can be utilized for pharmacological preconditioning against I/R injury, because it has already been proved that sublethal oxidative stress can increase tissue tolerance against lethal and sever ischemia. Putting all these together, there are open questions related to the application of CNTs to protect tissue against the oxidative stress. 93 The general mechanisms by which CNTs lead to cell toxicity has already been summarized on a review presented by Schedova et al., 2012. 94

sections.heading: 2.3. Polymeric nanoparticles
sections.text:
Polymeric NPs consistently show new and unique properties compared to their bulk state, due to quantum effects at nanoscales and increased surface to volume ratio. Two major categories of polymeric nanostructures are nanospheres and nanocapsules. nanospheres are matrix particles with solid mass and nanocapsules are vesicular systems with cavity consisting of a liquid core,

either water or oil.95 Even though, polymeric NPs does not provide direct antioxidant effects, but their involvement in antioxidant activities for tissue protection after I/R injury have been studied. 96, 97 In recent years, stimuli-responsive polymeric nanoparticles have shown great promise for treatment and detection of ischemic areas owing to changeability of their chemical structure and physicochemical properties in response to environmental stimuli including pH, ionic strength, temperature and light.98 The unique properties of ROS responsive polymeric nanoparticle such as the alteration in solubility in response to ROS and dual pH and ROSinduced degradation make them excellent candidates for ROS-responsive drug release or imaging of ischemic regions. 99 In the case of tellurium containing polymers, a ROS responsive polymeric nanoparticle, the oxidation of tellurium on the polymer backbone is account for the swelling and hydration of micelles in the presence of H2O2 (figure 6a,b). 100 The integration of aryloxalates via ester bond within the polymeric nanostructures contribute to their degradation and drug release in response to H2O2 because aryloxalates can react with H2O2 to form 1,2 dioxetanedione and subsequently decompose into carbon dioxide. 101
Most of these studies chemically incorporated an antioxidant agent on fully biodegradable hydroxybenzyl alcohol (HBA) to develop the effective antioxidant NPs. In the case of HBAincorporated polyoxalate copolymer (HPOX), the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of the HBA linked with H2O2 scavenging effects of polyoxalate copolymer. For instance, Lee et al. chemically incorporated HBA in the backbone of HPOX via covalent bonds to prepare an oxidation-responsive polymeric nanoparticle for detection and therapy of ischemia–reperfusion injury. The authors mentioned that HPOX can be used as H2O2 imaging agents because it is capable to react with H2O2 to perform peroxalate chemiluminescence reaction in the presence of fluorescent dyes(figure 6c). 102
Similar to the above-mentioned study, same group covalently incorporated vanillyl alcohol (VA) in the backbone of H2O2-responsive peroxalate ester to design a nanotherapeutic agent for I/R
injury and H2O2-associated disorders. 103 Similar to HPOX, PVAX was also exploited for H2O2 detection and imaging on ischemic tissue. The imaging section for this also could be bringing in related section. Moreover, same authors prepared poly (vanillin oxalate) (PVO) as a polymeric prodrug of vanillin (PVOX) to scavenge H2O2 and suppress generation of ROS under oxidative stress. As mentioned above, vanillin covalently (by both H2O2-responsive peroxalate ester bonds

sections.heading: 3. Nanocarriers for drug delivery to I/R injury
sections.text: Drug delivery is one of the most advanced applications of nanoparticles in medicine which is mainly based on polymer or liposome carriers. Nanocarriers could be harnessed for targeted delivery to specific organ or cells, increased solubility of the hydrophobic drugs, enhanced stability of peptides and oligonucleotides, as well as improved permeability and of drugs across blood brain barrier (BBB). 107 Different principles are used for carriers include dispersing or dissolving the drug within a polymer matrix, entrapping drug inside lipid vesicles, encapsulating or adsorbing the treatment agents on the nanoparticle surface (Figure 7). Main examples of polymer- and lipid- based drug delivery have been summarized in Table 2. In addition, there is two main strategies for site-specific drug delivery using nanocarriers; passive and active targeting. Passive targeting uses the unique vascular bed in the target organ or tissue to accumulate at that site, while on active targeting there are specific ligands on nanocarrier surface which binds to the extracellular markers of the target-cell. 108, 109 In the following, we mainly discuss the polymer- and liposome-based nanocarriers for the treatment of ischemic tissue injuries.

sections.heading: 3.1. Liposome nanocarriers
sections.text:
Liposomes are vesicular structures which mainly formed by self-assembly of the dissolved polar lipid molecules including hydrophobic and hydrophilic tails. Lipid-based nanovesciles can separate hydrophilic or hydrophobic molecules from the bulk solution. Beside their applications as carrier for cancer treatment, liposome NPs have also been used on delivery of drugs, proteins/peptides and genes to the ischemic site or cells. 110 Liposomes have been extensively applied as nanocarriers for targeted delivery of antioxidant agents. Numerous papers have shown that the physicochemical properties of liposomes such as charges, chemical composition, surface chemistry and surface functional groups determine their efficiency and behavior as nanocarriers for treatment and bioimaging of ischemic areas. Due to the acidic conditions in the cytosol of the ischemic cells and interstitial space of the ischemic tissue, basic lipids could be utilized for providing acid-sensitive nanoliposomes to release their cargos specifically in the ischemic site. 111 Phosphatidylethanolamines (PE)- and dioleoylphosphatidylethanolamine (DOPE)-based nanoliposomes are among the acidic sensitive liposomes which can release the encapsulated drugs on the ischemic penumbra. 112 The molecular shape of phospholipids and their high tendency for accumulation in inverse hexagonal phases instead of lamellar phases like in double layers result in their pH-sensitivity. 113 PH sensitive nanoliposomes are mainly stabilized with PEG to prevent from unwanted leakage or fusion, and equally increase their circulation time and therefore their bioavailability. Application of the naoliposomes for selective delivery of the

therapeutic agents to the ischemic brain regions is considered as a promising therapeutic approach. Nanoliposomes can cross the BBB by passive diffusion, through endocytosis, or by ligand-directed route. The liposome nanocarriers could be additionally functionalized for enhanced penetration through the BBB, increased circulation time and therefore increased bioavailability, as well as selectivity for the ischemic regions. These properties could decrease side effects and increase the efficacy of the drug. 114-116 Multifunctional liposomes can encompass all above mentioned characteristics by including pH-sensitive lipid-bases, PEGconjugation for increased circulation time as well as functional peptides for specific delivery. Studies on the cardiac I/R showed that positively charged liposomes passively accumulate on the ischemic regions of the myocardium, which later have extensively been utilized for selective delivery of drugs to the ischemic heart. 117-119 For instance, ATP-loaded liposome nanocarriers were specifically targeted the ischemic heart cells by antimyosin label and improved the systolic and diastolic pressure ex vivo and decreased infarct size in vivo. 120 Liposome conjugated ligand for angiotensin II type-1 receptor (AT1) specifically targeted the ischemic heart tissue which overexpresses AT1 receptors. 121 Nanoliposomes could also contain a solid matrix, including solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNPs) and nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs). These nanomaterials can combine the advantages of polymeric NPs, fat emulsions, and liposomes. 122 Poor absorption and stability at physiological pH, rapid metabolism, and rapid clearance of some antioxidant agents decrease their efficiency to enhance cell survival in ischemic regions. Unique surface chemistry of SLNPs and their ability for drug loading provides new horizons to solve this problems. 123, 124 Engineered nanoliposomes encapsulated the basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) on their solid core were applied from intranasal route, distributed mainly on the penumbra regions of the ischemic brain and lead to reduced infarct size and functional recovery. 110
3.2. Polymer-based nanocarriers
Polymeric nanocarriers (PNCs) are prepared from biocompatible and biodegradable polymers to dissolve (for nanospheres), entrap/encapsulate (for nanocapsule) or attach drugs to their matrix. 125 Different types of cargos including drugs, proteins and genes can be loaded onto the polymer nanocarriers to safely and specifically deliver to the target organ or tissue. Regarding their structural flexibility, functional groups and stability, PNCs are divided to the following categories: polymeric micelles (PM), polymeric nanocapsules (PNCPs), polymeric nanogels (PNGs), dendrimers (DDs), and hybrid nanoparticles with porous core (HNPCs). In recent years, various groups have reported targeted delivery based on ROS-responsive functional groups/or linkers such as boronic acid, sulfide, thioether and thioketal groups (figure 7b). The incorporation of these functional moieties in the polymeric backbone results in controlled release of drug in response to ROS. The mechanism of action for boronates as sensitive linkers relies on the oxidation-triggered hydrolysis of the boronic ester to a phenol and subsequently the nanoparticle degradation. Likewise, the mechanism of sulfide groups is based on the oxidative conversion of the hydrophobic sulfide moieties to the more-hydrophilic sulfoxides and sulfones 101 . On the

The internal pressure of the polymeric nanostructures increases in response to oxidative stress because H2O2 diffuses into the polymeric nanoparticle and generate gas owing to its interaction with other component. For instance, Sung et al. prepared a ROS-responsive hollow microsphere (HM) carrier including an anti-inflammatory drug, an acid precursor consisting of ethanol and FeCl2, and sodium bicarbonate (SBC) as a bubble generating agent. Low concentration of H2O2 could diffuse into HM and oxidize their encapsulated ethanol in the presence of Fe 2+ by the Fenton reaction to cause acidic condition which, in turn, resulted in decomposition of SBC to CO2 bubbles and subsequent release of drug (figure 7c). 126
In addition, polymer-drug and -protein conjugates are also widely used on cancer treatment which could also be exploited for I/R injury treatments.127

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Polymer-drug or polymer-protein conjugates
sections.text:
The reduced toxicity and improved efficacy in clinical applications of the covalently bonded
polymer-drug or -protein conjugates including PEGylated enzymes or cytokines and polymer-
bound chemotherapy drugs, have already offered the opportunities for the treatment of ischemia-
induced oxidative stress. For instance, engineered polymer-drug conjugate (Poly-l-glutamic acid
(PGA)-inhibitors of apoptotic protease activating factor 1 (Apaf-1)) limited hypoxia induced
apoptosis. 130 Polyethylene glycol (PEG)-nitric oxide (NO) conjugates improved endothelial
dysfunction and reduced vasoconstriction after cheek pouch I/R injury in hamsters. 131 Owing to
their outstanding properties such as super high capacity of drug loading, high degree of
homogeneity, reduced burst release, multivalency, improved pharmacokinetics relative to other
polymeric nanoparticles with physically encapsulate drugs, predictable conformations in solution
and the possibility to use various stimuli-responsive linkers for the design smart polymer–drug
conjugates, polymer-drug or polymer-protein conjugates have aroused much attention for
targeted drug delivery to the sites of ROS stress. The peptide, ester and amide linkers are
commonly used in polymer–drug conjugates and can be hydrolytically and/or enzymatically
broken in the sites of ischemia.132, 133 Moreover, the use of the pH-responsive chemical bonds
such as hydrazone and cis-acotinyl into structure of polymer-drug conjugates result in controlled
release of drug under mild acidic condition in ischemic regions and cancer. 134 Some examples of
smart conjugated polymer-drugs have been summarized in Table 3.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Polymeric micelles
sections.text:
Polymer micelles are provided from amphiphilic block or graft copolymers in the aqueous
solution. The hydrophobic core of the polymeric micelles makes them a suitable carrier for
poorly water-soluble drugs. 135 Biocompatibility, longer circulation time and higher capacity for
loading drugs are considered as advantages of polymeric micelles. Polymeric micelles can be
used as carriers for antioxidant drugs or be functionalized for sensing pH and ROS to target the
ischemic organ for drug delivery. 136 Free radical scavenger agents which are not soluble in the
normal pH could also be incorporated into the polymer micelles to increase their circulation time
and efficacy. 137 Incorporation into the hydrophobic core of the polymeric micelles also prevented
from disintegration of nitroxyl radicals, ROS scavenger, in lower pH of the ischemic tissue. 138
The some examples of smart polymeric micelles have been mentioned in Table 3.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Polymeric nanocapsules
sections.text:
Polymeric nanocapsules (PNCPs), with an aqueous core surrounded by a hydrophobic domain,
are exhibit potential for delivery of therapeutic agent into the ischemic tissue. 139 Owing to
changeability of physiochemical properties of some block-copolymers in the presence of
biologically relevant stimulus(pH, temperature) and external energy source (magnetic field,
light), PNCPs can be applied as excellent smart nanoreactors or artificial organelles to treat
ischemia regions(figure 8 a). 140 For instance, integration of a pH sensitive monomer in the
hydrophobic block lead to formation of smart PNCPs. Sensitive monomer becomes hydrophilic
and releases drug in response to pH changes in the sites of ischemia/ROS stress. 141 The some
examples of smart polymeric nanocapsules have been mentioned in Table 3.

Moreover, the PNCPs provided from PLGA were used for encapsulating insoluble antioxidant
flavonoid quercetin (QC) to improve its BBB penetration. The PLGA-QC nanocapsules were
successfully delivered to the ischemic brain and decreased mitochondrial damage, expression of
iNOS and proapoptotic proteins in young and aged rats, while QC by itself could not protect
brain I/R-injury. 142

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Polymeric nanogels
sections.text:
Polymeric nanogels are self-assembled amphiphilic copolymers locked by different cross-
linking methods. 143 Polymeric nanogels are water soluble and biocompatible materials with
stable encapsulation properties.144 Polymeric nanogels have been exploited for sustained and
long-term delivery of protective agents to the ischemic tissue. For instance, ultrapure alginate
hydrogels were used for dual delivery of angiogenic VEGF and myogenic insulin-like growth
factor 1 (IGF1) to the ischemic muscle after limb I/R injury. Encapsulation in biodegradable
polymer hydrogels leads to more functional recovery, sustained and localized release of
VEGF/IGF1 to the ischemic regions. 145
Negatively charged heparin nanogels encapsulated basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and
were coated with polyethylenimine (PEI) on the surface to complex it with pDNA coding the
VEGF165 (Figure ). This complex promoted endothelial progenitor cells differentiation to the
mature endothelial cells which finally lead to neovascularization in hind limb model of
ischemia. 146 Due to the shielding effect of heparin, its conjugation with PEI improved in vivo
gene transfection efficacy of PEI. Same to the polymeric micelles, the polymeric nanogles can
be self-assembled from “smart” block-copolymers to form stimuli‐responsive nanogels for drug
delivery and cell imaging. 147 For instance, Urokinase, a thrombolytic agent which has already

3.1.3. Dendrimers
Dendrimers are hyperbranched tree-like polymers with high density of functional groups on their
surface and small molecular volume, which are also considered as monomolecular polymer
micelles. Dendrimers comprised of three parts: single atom or atomic groups in center, repeating
units forming several interior layers and multiple functional groups located at surface.
Depending on the amphiphilic property and interior cavities, dendrimers can be applied for
encapsulating hydrophobic and hydrophilic drugs. 149 It has been shown that injected dendrimers
are automatically and selectively taken up by ischemic and traumatic brain regions. 150
Dendrimers, such as poly (amido amine) (PAMAM), can be linked to drugs or therapeutic
molecules to deliver them with higher concentrations to the ischemic region or within the
ischemic cells and increase their circulation time.151, 152 In addition to the ischemic organ,
dendrimers can target the inflammatory cells including activated macrophages and microglia
cells. 150 In addition to drug delivery, some studies have used dendrimers for gene delivery to the
various ischemic organs and through different administration routes.153 For example, the
PAMAM dendrimer coupled with arginine-grafted poly (disulfide amine) (ABP) (PAM-ABP)
was applied in delivering the plasmid DNA with hypoxia response element (HR1) to the
ischemic heart. The PAM-ABP improved cellular uptake of the HR1 and increased its retention
on the extracellular matrix. 154 On the other hand, stimuli-responsive dendrimers or smart
dendrimers have been found to be promising candidates as carriers to treat ischemia areas
because they release payloads at targeted sites or at constant release profiles in response to a
specific trigger. In the case of acid-responsive dendrimers, drug conjugates to dendrimer via
acid-labile bonds such as hydrazine linkage and the boronate ester bonds. Acid-responsive
dendrimers are stable at pH 7.4, but are cleavable in acidic milieu or in the sites of ROS stress.

responsive dendrimer containing 5-aminosalicylic acid drug via an azo-containing linker to
inhibit inflammation in colon. Nanocarrier was stable in stomach and small intestine while
strongly released drug in colon owing to the presence of azoreductase(figure 9 b). 156 The some
examples of smart dendrimers have been mentioned in Table 3.

sections.heading: 4. Nanoparticles as imaging and diagnostic tools
sections.text:
Beside their therapeutic and delivery applications, nanomaterials can also be exploited as
molecular probes for different imaging modalities to determine the location and diagnose disease
process. 158-160 To visualize, monitor or record spatiotemporal distribution of molecular and
cellular processes, imaging modalities such as optical imaging (luminescence and fluorescence),
radionucleotide-based imaging [positron emission tomography (PET), single photon emission
computed tomography (SPECT)], magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed tomography
(CT) and ultrasound need specific molecular probes to target molecules, cells or tissues and
allow them to be imaged. 161 In general, imaging probes consists of three elements signal agent,
target and linker which has been summarized in (Figure 10a). A desired molecular imaging
probe should provide high binding affinity and specificity to target, high sensitivity and high
stability in vivo as well as less toxicity. Macrophages are one of the pivotal components in
mediating tissue damage in the sites of ROS stress and ischemic regions. Owing to their short
lifetime and nanomolar or lower range of H2O2 level (an important endogenous ROS in
macrophages), smart and high sensitive probes containing H2O2-reactive moieties are essential
for real-time imaging and the visualization of H2O2 in macrophages. 162
Compared to the protein imaging markers, nanoparticles with the same size are highly flexible
to the modifications and therefore provide versatile platforms for engineering multimodal and
multifunctional imaging agents for in vivo imaging. 163 For instance, a typical antibody loses its
antigen-recognition functionality after 10 substitutions, while nanoparticle of the same size can
bare 1500 modification sites. 164
Nanoparticles can improve signal quality in less-sensitive imaging techniques (CT and MRI) by
encapsulating large payloads of contrast materials and target delivery of them into the desired

Among the various NPs used in potential diagnostic applications, IONPs are the only one
which has been successfully incorporated into the clinical applications.167 The IONPs with
superparamagnetic property have extensively been applied as contrast agent for MRI because of
their biocompatibility, high relaxivity, non-toxicity and nonimmunogenicity in biological
systems. 168 The superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIONs) with size range of 20-25 nm shows
rapid filliping rate in response to the applied magnetic field. 169 The SPIONs have diverse
therapeutic and diagnostic applications in cerebral ischemic disease and stroke, including their
use as contrast agent for affected regions of brain and BBB after ischemia or stroke, perfusion-
weight MRI sequences for imaging vessels and regional blood flow after ischemia, and
degeneration as well as tracing implanted or inflammatory cells after injury. 170, 171 SPIONs, as
contrast agents on MRI, speed up the early diagnosis of ischemic lesions and assists on detecting
the infraction core and penumbra regions.172 Since the ultrasmall superparamagnetic iron oxide
(USPIONs) are taken up by macrophages and inflammatory cells in the body, they can be used to
trace them, too. The USPION enhanced MRI was applied to determine the macrophage
infiltration after ischemic stroke in human subjects. 173 Comparing the USPION-induced MRI
signal alterations and distribution of the iron-laden macrophages on the histological studies of
the same brain section in the animal models proved the visualization of the macrophage
infiltration into the ischemic region by USPION-enhanced MRI.174 The SPION-enhanced MRI
offers a non-invasive method for long-term follow up of inflammatory process and monitoring
long-term outcomes after ischemic stroke. 175 The SPION-enhanced MRI gives the possibility to
trace the systemic or locally transplanted stem cells into different brain regions. 176, 177 In a case
study by Jozwiak et al., cord blood-derived neural progenitor cells were labeled with SPIONs
and transplanted into the intracerebroventricular areas of 16-month old child suffering from

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Gold nanoparticles
sections.text:
The GNPs have many subtypes with various physical properties due to their size and shapes
(including nanospheres, nanorods, nanoshells and nanocages). Several advantages of GNPs over
liposomes and polymer micelles are flexibility to be fabricated in narrow range of sizes,
nanoparticle surface energy transfer (NEST) and fuorescence quenching. 179 Beside their intrinsic
antioxidant and anti-apoptotic properties, GNPs can be used as carriers for drugs or imaging
agents to the ischemic regions. High molecular weight fluorescein-hyaluronic acid (HA)
conjugated to GNPs are degraded in the presence of ROS and emits strong flurescence-recovery
signals which are applied for designing ROS-sensitive Au nanoprobes and imaging ROS levels
in ischemic cells or tissue. The GNP-HAs are fluorescence quenched in non-ROS conditions,
due to the NEST, while emit strong fluorescence signals in the presence of ROS, due to the HA
cleavage. 180 In an another report, GNP -HA injected locally to the brain before ischemia and
near infrared fluorescence signals were imaged 6 to 36 hours after ischemia in brain slices. The
results showed that ROS reaches to its peak at 24 hours after cerebral ischemia (figure 11) 179

Myocardial scar thickness and size could be used as an index for myocardial viability after
infarction. GNPs were coated by collagen adhesive peptide (CNA35) to target the myocardial
scars one month after ischemia reperfusion and imaged by CT. 181 Ex vivo images of the ischemic
core is also possible with surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) spectroscopy of gold
nanostructures named gold nanocoral (GNC), which sensed the spatial distribution of ATP,
ADP, AMP, adenosine, inosine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine at acute phase of the cerebral
ischemia. 182 Another application of GNPs on diagnosis of the ischemia is in vivo cell tracking by
multiple imaging modalities. 183 Depending on the physicochemical properties of gold
nanoparticles such as shape, size and surface chemistry, their absorption characteristics can be
tuned to maximally absorb in the near infrared region. Owing to surface plasmon resonance, they
display superior optical absorption properties as excellent photoacoustic contrast agents.
Surprisingly, different shapes of gold nanoparticles can be used to distinguish visualization both
delivered stem cells and macrophages in ischemic areas because of different their maximal
absorption( gold nanorods in the near-infrared region, gold nanospheres in the visible light
region (520 nm) and endocytosed gold nanospheres by macrophages in optical window of 650–
900 nm). 184
Currently, multi-photon luminescence of gold nanoparticles has been found to make them
fascinating materials for molecular imaging of cerebral vasculature and BBB integrity under

sections.heading: 4.2. Micelles for diagnosis of I/R injury
sections.text:
Beside the delivery of the therapeutic agents by polymeric micelles, surfactant micelles, PEG-
micelles, lipid-base micelles and targeted micelles can also be applied in imaging and diagnostic
purposes. 186 In the ischemic organ, the leaky vascular system enhances the permeability and
retention rate (EPR) of micelles. 187 Therefore, micelles can be utilized to achieve higher
concentration of imaging reporters and deliver them to the ischemic region.
Vascular disruption and plasma leakage in acute and chronic inflamed tissues was imaged by
fluorescence molecular tomography which detected the near-infrared (NIR) cyanine dye-doped
into aqueous micelles. 188 Moreover, Yokoyama et al. used a polymeric micelle magnetic
resonance imaging (MRI) contrast agent (Gd-micelles) for visualization of hyper-permeability in
the BBB in cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury. 187
As mentioned above for targeted drug delivery, stimuli-responsive polymeric micelles or
smart polymeric micelles can be used as nanocarrier for targeted delivery and controlled release
of ultrasensitive probes to monitor ischemic areas. Recently, Lee et al. developed a pH-
responsive biodegradable polymeric micelle system based on typical ring opening
polymerization of N-carboxyanhydrides (NCAs-ROP) using mPEG-NH2 as a macroinitiator for
synthesis of the mPEG-b-P(DPA-DE)LG copolymer and a sequential aminolysis reaction to
graft pH-sensitive ligands and two types of amine-terminated dopamine groups onto side chain.
The author mentioned that the dopamine groups facilitated self-assembly and subsequent
enhanced long-term stability because of their high-affinity to iron oxide nanoparticles. In
ischemic tissue, changes in pH resulted in release of MRI probes and enhancement of negative

4.3. Liposomes
Liposomes, the same as micelles, are passively targeting the ischemic regions with slower
accumulation rate (relating to their larger sizes (~100 nm) compared to micelles (~15 nm)).
Liposomes can be used to deliver contrast agents to desired tissue in a controlled manner.
Liposome - surface anchoring of contrast agents can retain their efficacy and subsequently
decrease their toxicity. 191 As a promising example, Kong et al. developed a liposome coated
with MRI contrast agents using chitosan conjugated with octadecyl chains and
diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) as polymeric fastener which contributed to
immobilization of chelated gadolinium onto the surface of liposomes through electrostatic and
hydrophobic assembly. The chitosan-coated, cross-linked liposomes improved their integrity and
controlled delivery of gadolinium to ischemic site (figure 13a). 192
4.3. Polymeric nanoparticles and dendrimers
Polymeric NPs and dendrimers can be used for coating the imaging agents in order to increase
their circulation time and mitigate their toxicity, resulting in better delivery into the target
ischemic region and so enhancing the recorded signals. 193, 194 Regarding the lower intrinsic
contrast of the kidney, application of polymer-based contrast agents enhances the MRI contrast.
The amino groups on the outer surface of the dendrimers can be conjugated with MRI contrast
agents and be used for imaging. 195 Large dendrimers with lower renal excretion rate remains in
the circulation and are used for imaging vessels. Large hydrophobic dendrimers accumulate in
spleen and liver can be used for imaging these two organs and small dendrimers with rapid

accumulate in renal tubules which are the main functional units in kidney and target of ischemic
injury. In the experimental acute renal failure, PAMAM-based dendrimer-based MRI contrast
agents, with smaller dendrimer sizes, helped to non-invasively diagnose ischemia-induced
tubular damage and renal injury before the serum creatinine is elevated. 196 A non-invasive
imaging method to study angiogenesis is highly required for monitoring the probable effects of
the treatments on angiogenesis after ischemia. Almutairi et al. engineered a dendrimer-based
PET nanoprobe to target specifically angiogenesis after hind limb ischemia. Polyethylene oxide
(PEO) chains formed protective shell for 76Br and in the surface conjugated with targeting
peptides cyclic arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD) to target αVβ3 integrin receptor which is
highly expressed in the areas of angiogenesis. The probe improved bioavailability of 76Br, its
binding and specificity to the tissue with higher αVβ3 integrin expression. 197 Understanding the
pathological signals such changes in pH, oxygen levels, hypoxia and the cellular oxidative state
are of utmost importance for design of smart polymeric nanoparticles and further development of
molecular imaging because of their close association with oxidative stress related disease and
cancer. 198 As a promising example of smart polymeric nanoparticles in molecular imaging, Sung
et al. prepared a dual-responsive nanoparticle system containing Cy3 dye, encapsulated
curcumin (as anti-inflammatory agent), a hydrophobic copolymer poly-(1,4-phenyleneactone
dimethylene thioketal)(PPADT) (as a pH-responsive and oxidative stress responsive group)
based on interaction between both hydrophobic moieties and N-palmitoyl groups of Cy3 dye and
the amine groups of backbone of the chitosan polymer. The hydrophobic interactions led to self-
assembly of the nanoparticles at pH 7.4. The smart polymeric nanoparticle system was degraded
into PPADT hydrophilic components in the acidic milieu produced by activated macrophages

sections.heading: 4.4. Toxicity of nanomaterials
sections.text:
Besides the several advantages which nanoparticles offering as antioxidant drugs or nanocarriers,
the potential citotoxicity induced by them should be considered carefully. However, the focus of
the present study is not on the toxicities induced by nanoparticles. The toxicity can be related to
ROS generations and inflammatory reactions. Below we included few examples of potential
citotoxic properties:
It has ave been reported that CeONPs can cause an inflammatory response in vivo via pro-
inflammatory cytokines production that largely depends on mast cell activation, and exacerbated
myocardial I/R injury. 201 Pan et al., reported that Au NPs with diameter of 1.4 nm can induce
mitochondrial damage and release free radicals which causes cellular necrosis. 202 Many studies
show that Ag NPs can lead to oxidative stress, genotoxicity and apoptosis in cultured cells or
tissue. 203-207 The known mechanisms for Ag NPs induced cellular toxicity include massive ROS
production, depletion of antioxidant glutathione, increased caspase-3 activity and intracellular
calcium, as well as DNA damage. 208, 209 Fullerenes C60 which have been frequently reported as
antioxidant agenst, can paradoxically act as both oxidants and antioxidants. Wingard et al.
reported that C60 fullerene increases cardiac I/R injury, and coronary artery contraction in
spraguedawley rats. 69, 210 Lai reported that polyhydroxylated fullerene derivatives C60(OH)72 at

high concentrations leads to the cellular apoptosis or necrosis, while at low concentrations
protect against oxidative stress after lung I/R injury. 211 MWCNTs increases ROS generation and
decreases activity of antioxidant enzymes like CAT and glutathione reductase (GR) through
activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) and mitogen-activated protein kinase
(MAPK) signaling pathway. 212, 213 Despite the acute oxidative effect of PEGylated single-wall
CNTs (SWCNT-PEG) on rat hippocampus, its long-term effect, one week after injection,
appeared by increased expression of the genes for antioxidant enzymes, improved antioxidant
defense and reduced ROS production. 92 The general mechanisms by which CNTs lead to cell
toxicity has been summarized on the review by Schedova et al. 94 Concerning graphene as one of
the most promising biocompatible nanomaterials with carbon-based structure (carbon can be
considered as the most compatible structure with organisms and tissues), nearly all reports
including cell growths on surfaces of graphene sheets indicated its biocompatibility. 75, 214
However, there are some other investigations regarding the size and concentration-dependent
cyto- and geno-toxicities of graphene against stem cells, bacteria, spermatozoa and even
animals. 215, 216 Nanoscale graphene sheets (including graphene nanoplatelets and nanoribbons) at
high concentrations (typically >100 µg/mL) could induce significant toxicities, resulting in, e.g.,
cell death, DNA fragmentations and/or chromosomal aberrations of alive cells and disturbance in
animal hormone secretions. Hence, further investigations are highly required to better understand
and then minimize the mechanisms involved in toxicity of nanomaterials (even carbon-based
ones). Until this moment, the following mechanisms have been established for describing the
potential toxicity of graphene: 1) physical interaction of ultra-sharp edges of graphene with cell
memberanes, 2) ROS generation, and 3) capturing cells by aggregating graphene sheets in a
suspension. 217, 218 Although, functionalization of graphene and protein corona effect can decrease

the toxic effects, these mechanisms may still be occurred in diagnosis and treatments followed
by graphene release in body and hence should be studied with more details to control the

controversy with protective effects of nanomaterials in coping with oxidative stress and IR
injury. For these controversial results, a number of groups including our group have reported that
biological behavior and the toxicity of nanomaterials strongly is associated with their
fabrication methods and the physicochemical properties such as structure, surface chemistry,
size, charge and functional groups. 220, 221 It was found that the toxicity of nanomaterials can be
controlled by their surface chemistry and synthetic methods. 222, 223

sections.heading: 4.5. Bloodstream circulation and clearance patterns of nanomaterials
sections.text:
Circulation features and clearance patterns of nanomaterials have been singled out for great
health concern since their toxic effects have not been known completely. Various factors
including the surface charge, size, shape, surface-to-volume ratio and functionalized groups
influence the bloodstream circulation and organ clearance. Moreover, they can affect protein
adsorption, aggregation, agglomeration, surface reactivity and toxicity of nanomaterials. 103 High
surface energy of nanomaterial confers protein adsorption through the interfacial reactions which
in turn resulted in protein corona formation around the nanoparticles. 224 Protein corona may
influence the blood circulation half-life of nanomaterial. 225 Composition of the protein corona
can determine the blood circulation, biodistribution, clearance profiles and fate of nanomaterials
in body. 226 Opsonin protein absorbtion may enhance clearance of nanomaterial by RES
macrophages through rapid uptake into the liver and the spleen tissues. Functionalization of
nanomaterial by poly (ethylene glycol) (PEG) can decrease absorption of opsonin proteins via
steric repulsion that increase their blood circulation and retention time. Protein corona may

hamper targeting of nanomaterial to desired tissues via lose their targeting capabilities. 227 On
other hand, absorbtion of certain apolipoproteins to particle surface can improve across the blood
brain barrier (BBB) into the brain or to desired tissues. 228 Moreover, protein corona may prevent
cell damage and decrease cell uptake in various tissues via reduction unspecific and strong
interactions of nanomaterial with the cell membranes. 229 A recent study has been shown that
protein corona can guard against ROS-induced toxicity in human macrophages via inhibition of
mitochondrial damage and inflammation by Fe3O4-PEG nanoparticles. 230 Beside protein
absorption, different factors such as size, shape and surface chemistry may influence the location
and biodistribution of nanomaterials. Kupffer cells of the liver, the spleen macrophages and the
reticuloendothelial system (RES) play an important role in rapid clearance nanomaterial of blood
circulation, thereby high dose of them may cause hepatotoxicity and spleen damage. Degradation
and metabolism of many nanomaterials such as Polymer-based nanostructures and
superparamagnetic iron oxide have been identified that decrease their toxicity whereas other
nanomaterial such as fullerenes, QDs and silica NPs did not degrade in vivo. 231 The degradability
of carbon-based materials (especially graphene) is highly desirable in various bio-applications,
since graphene showed some potentials for degradation under UV and NIR irradiations.216, 232
Inert nanomaterials may metabolize by many enzymes. In addition, the body may eliminate
nanomaterials via exhaled breath, the biliary duct, saliva, seminal fluids and the kidneys. 233

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future perspective
sections.text:
Numerous attempts by many groups around the world have been made to improve the design
of new materials and devices for treatment and diagnosis of IR injury because it is leading
cause of seriously debilitating diseases such as ischemic stroke and myocardial infarction.

Unfortunately, numerous protective drugs and contrast agents have failed to show benefit in
the diagnosis and the treatment of ischemic regions and the sites of ROS stress. Targeted
delivery, controlled release of drug and contrast agents and enhanced specificity of targeted
imaging remains the main challenge to improve quality of life and clinical outcomes in of
patients with ischemic stroke and myocardial infarction, because of the toxicity, short blood
circulation time, fast metabolization, poor diffusion across the blood–brain barrier (BBB),
blood-testis barrier and blood–spinal cord barrier (BSCB), poor solubility and serious side
effects of most antioxidant drugs and contrast agents. On the other hand, effective treatment
of these serious debilitating disorders has been often challenged by concerns regarding great
degree of their complexity and the mechanisms involved in human. Nanomaterials for
targeted therapy and visualization, as well as “payload” release in desired tissue have
attracted widespread attention from the scientific community in recent years. Understanding
the biochemical changes in ischemic organs, smart material design (biodegradability and
biocompatibility), physicochemical properties (surface chemistry, size, charge, shape,
functionality, molecular imaging probes) might overcome the barriers for future safe and
effective molecular imaging and treatment of ischemic stroke and myocardial infarction.
How to conquer the realization of such eclectic approaches for routine clinical use is a
challenging task for our future research.

metadata.abstractText: Organ ischemia with inadequate oxygen supply followed by reperfusion (which initiates a complex of inflammatory responses and oxidative stress) occurs in different clinical conditions and surgical procedures including stroke, myocardial infarction, limb ischemia, renal failure, organ transplantation, free-tissue-transfer, cardiopulmonary bypass, and vascular surgery. Even though pharmacological treatment protect against experimental ischemia reperfusion (I/R) injury, there has not been enough success for their applications in patient benefits. The main hurdles in treatment of I/R injury are the lack of diagnosis tools for understanding the complicated chains of I/R-induced signaling events, especially in acute phase after ischemia, determining the affected regions of the tissue over time, and then, targeting and safe delivery of antioxidants, drugs, peptides, genes and cells to the areas required treatment. Beside the innate antioxidant and free radical scavenging properties of some nanoparticles, they show higher flexibilities in drug delivery and imaging purposes. This review highlights three main approaches on I/R injury targeting by nanoparticles; 1) antioxidant nanoparticles on reducing tissue oxidative stress, 2) targeted delivery of therapeutic agents to the ischemic regions or cells, and 3) imaging I/R injury at molecular, cellular or tissue level and monitoring its evolution using contrasts induced by nanoparticles. These approaches can also be combined to realize so called theranostics for providing simultaneous diagnosis of ischemic regions and treatments by targeted delivery.
